But after five weeks in office, it's become clear that Mr. Obama's policies are slowing, if not stopping, what would otherwise be the normal process of economic recovery." "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123604419092515347.html" C.R. It's all but impossible to judge a ruined economy, 8 yrs in the making, by a few short weeks of work trying to fix it. It took Reagan almost 18 months before the Carter debacle started to turn around, and what we have today isn't even close to what transpired under Carter. content: Here is a link to the actual poll #'s: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/polls/postpoll_033109.html?hpid=topnews" The headline isn't entirely accurate. From the poll: quote: 7. How much blame do you think [ITEM] deserve(s) for the country's economic situation - a great deal, a good amount, only some or hardly any? Obama's #'s: Great Deal 13%, Good Deal 13%, Only Some 27%, Hardly Any 39%, None 6% That means that 53% of those polled feel that the POTUS has at least some blame in the "country's economic situation". In fact, according to those polled they feel that the banks, businesses, and consumers are more to blame for the economy than Bush. The people polled are also split almost down the middle on what is more important right now, increasing spending or decreasing the defecit(49% to 47%). Interesting poll.
quote: 7. How much blame do you think [ITEM] deserve(s) for the country's economic situation - a great deal, a good amount, only some or hardly any?
reply: Here is a link to the actual poll #'s: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/polls/postpoll_033109.html?hpid=topnews" The headline isn't entirely accurate. From the poll:  Obama's #'s: Great Deal 13%, Good Deal 13%, Only Some 27%, Hardly Any 39%, None 6% That means that 53% of those polled feel that the POTUS has at least some blame in the "country's economic situation". In fact, according to those polled they feel that the banks, businesses, and consumers are more to blame for the economy than Bush. The people polled are also split almost down the middle on what is more important right now, increasing spending or decreasing the defecit(49% to 47%). Interesting poll.
title: Voters Don't Blame Obama for Economy

content: The OP is correct, the current economy is not Obama's, but rather it is his reaction to policies past (both Dem and Repub). At some unknown date in the future it may become "his", but I suspect he is no hurry to make the transition.

content: quote: Originally posted by jack_flats: quote: Originally posted by CYCLIC_RUNAWAY: Oh really? "Americans have welcomed the Obama era in the same spirit of hope the President campaigned on. But after five weeks in office, it's become clear that Mr. Obama's policies are slowing, if not stopping, what would otherwise be the normal process of economic recovery." "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123604419092515347.html" C.R. It's all but impossible to judge a ruined economy, 8 yrs in the making, by a few short weeks of work trying to fix it. It took Reagan almost 18 months before the Carter debacle started to turn around, and what we have today isn't even close to what transpired under Carter. Jack - Your logic is flawed, your mathmatic's is non-existant. First the protest, Bush you stated in the last 8 years gave us the bad economic's is dead arse wrong. It started in 1999 with a combination of events. To accept your thoughts you must heap some of your illogical blame on the Senate/House in the same time period. President Obama was in the Senate in 2004. But neither he or Bush were involved. In the previous year 2003 the Secretary of Tresury warned that Freddie and Fannie needed to be reined in. In 2005 S190 of the Shelby committee to regulate lending practies of Fannie, Freddie and banking. By a partisan vote including Senator Dodd the bill was tabled never to see the daylight again. When the Shiite hit the fan in 2007 2008 the language of this bill that finally passed Congress was close to the one previous (S190) by the Senate to regain authority of the lending institutions. The bill in 1999 co-author in the Senate and House relax restriction on credit, diversity in banking, clearing houses, insurance etc. Senator Gramm (R)and House Members Jim Leach (R) were the original authors. It past both Houses and stymied in the joint committee only to be compromised when an insertion of Community Reinvestment was made by Democratic members. President Clinton Signed the bill in December 1999. George Bush has nothing to apologize for nor the members of the Congress of that year. It was in 2003 and 2005 when members were warned, had advance notice given by Secretary of Treasury, HUD, and other agencies without taking action. The one name that appears often than any other is Dodd.
quote: Originally posted by jack_flats: quote: Originally posted by CYCLIC_RUNAWAY: Oh really? "Americans have welcomed the Obama era in the same spirit of hope the President campaigned on. But after five weeks in office, it's become clear that Mr. Obama's policies are slowing, if not stopping, what would otherwise be the normal process of economic recovery." "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123604419092515347.html" C.R. It's all but impossible to judge a ruined economy, 8 yrs in the making, by a few short weeks of work trying to fix it. It took Reagan almost 18 months before the Carter debacle started to turn around, and what we have today isn't even close to what transpired under Carter.

It started in 1999 with a combination of events. To accept your thoughts you must heap some of your illogical blame on the Senate/House in the same time period. President Obama was in the Senate in 2004. But neither he or Bush were involved. In the previous year 2003 the Secretary of Tresury warned that Freddie and Fannie needed to be reined in. In 2005 S190 of the Shelby committee to regulate lending practies of Fannie, Freddie and banking. By a partisan vote including Senator Dodd the bill was tabled never to see the daylight again. When the Shiite hit the fan in 2007 2008 the language of this bill that finally passed Congress was close to the one previous (S190) by the Senate to regain authority of the lending institutions. The bill in 1999 co-author in the Senate and House relax restriction on credit, diversity in banking, clearing houses, insurance etc. Senator Gramm (R)and House Members Jim Leach (R) were the original authors. It past both Houses and stymied in the joint committee only to be compromised when an insertion of Community Reinvestment was made by Democratic members. President Clinton Signed the bill in December 1999. George Bush has nothing to apologize for nor the members of the Congress of that year. It was in 2003 and 2005 when members were warned, had advance notice given by Secretary of Treasury, HUD, and other agencies without taking action. The one name that appears often than any other is Dodd.

It was in 2003 and 2005 when members were warned, had advance notice given by Secretary of Treasury, HUD, and other agencies without taking action. The one name that appears often than any other is Dodd.
quote: Originally posted by jack_flats: quote: Originally posted by CYCLIC_RUNAWAY: Oh really? "Americans have welcomed the Obama era in the same spirit of hope the President campaigned on. But after five weeks in office, it's become clear that Mr. Obama's policies are slowing, if not stopping, what would otherwise be the normal process of economic recovery." "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123604419092515347.html" C.R. It's all but impossible to judge a ruined economy, 8 yrs in the making, by a few short weeks of work trying to fix it. It took Reagan almost 18 months before the Carter debacle started to turn around, and what we have today isn't even close to what transpired under Carter.
reply: Jack - Your logic is flawed, your mathmatic's is non-existant. First the protest, Bush you stated in the last 8 years gave us the bad economic's is dead arse wrong. It started in 1999 with a combination of events. To accept your thoughts you must heap some of your illogical blame on the Senate/House in the same time period. President Obama was in the Senate in 2004. But neither he or Bush were involved. In the previous year 2003 the Secretary of Tresury warned that Freddie and Fannie needed to be reined in. In 2005 S190 of the Shelby committee to regulate lending practies of Fannie, Freddie and banking. By a partisan vote including Senator Dodd the bill was tabled never to see the daylight again. When the Shiite hit the fan in 2007 2008 the language of this bill that finally passed Congress was close to the one previous (S190) by the Senate to regain authority of the lending institutions. The bill in 1999 co-author in the Senate and House relax restriction on credit, diversity in banking, clearing houses, insurance etc. Senator Gramm (R)and House Members Jim Leach (R) were the original authors. It past both Houses and stymied in the joint committee only to be compromised when an insertion of Community Reinvestment was made by Democratic members. President Clinton Signed the bill in December 1999. George Bush has nothing to apologize for nor the members of the Congress of that year. It was in 2003 and 2005 when members were warned, had advance notice given by Secretary of Treasury, HUD, and other agencies without taking action. The one name that appears often than any other is Dodd.
title: Voters Don't Blame Obama for Economy

content: Something will have to be done soon I suspect. Other Nations are ready to make this new currency a done deal. In a way it would be good for the US to be a leader and make it happen. I don't understand what the hold up is on this. Geithner is for it and so are other key members of the Obama staff. I'm also for it. Maybe they are waiting to see what happens at the G20 meeting.
reply: Something will have to be done soon I suspect. Other Nations are ready to make this new currency a done deal. In a way it would be good for the US to be a leader and make it happen. I don't understand what the hold up is on this. Geithner is for it and so are other key members of the Obama staff. I'm also for it. Maybe they are waiting to see what happens at the G20 meeting.
